prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The velocity resolution of the observations ranges from 0.23 km/s for strong lines and 0.46 km/s for either weak lines or to obtain more bandwidth to cover multiple lines (i.e. for BB (2),SPW (a): C3H2 and CH3OH). The expected line width is ~1-1.5 km/s (and higher in the inner disk; Rosenfeld+2012). Because we are most interested in mapping the flux spatially and not spectrally, we plan to integrate the data cubes over velocity for all lines to obtain moment 0 maps to trace out the radial structure.

We have specified an angular resolution of 0.2'' (D~11 AU, R~5.5 AU) for all spectral set ups to resolve the water snow line in TW Hya (~4.7 AU, Zhang+2013), and to map the chemical behavior across all of the major transitions in the disk. The largest angular scale as determined from observations of CO 3-2 (the maximum extent of the molecular emission) in individual velocity channels is 6''.

Our limiting flux estimate is set by the need to detect one of 13CO or C18O 3-2 in the outer disk as CO is central to the chemistry of the disk. Based on the 13CO 6-5 detected in a 0.4'' beam as part of ALMA program 2012.1.00422.S (PI Bergin), if the emission is thin, the outer disk C18O 3-2 should have a peak flux of 4 mJy. Correspondingly we set our limit to detect C18O 3-2 in the outer disk only if 13CO is optically thick. We will readily detect C18O 3-2 (and 13CO) within the CO snow line, with an expected flux of 140 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN-iso, HCO+ and iso, sulfur, CO

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral resolution is 0.21 km/s for all bands except those containing 15N isotopologues, specifically HC15N and H15NC. The 14N/15N abundance is uncertain but is expected to be low (~300) and so these lines will be difficult to detect (they will only be detected if H13CN is optically thick). We have correspondingly set their channel width to 0.42 km/s, which also widens the bandwidth to cover additional SO and S18O lines. The lines are expected to be 1-1.5 km/s in the outer disk and higher in the inner disk (Rosenfeld+2012), and so we will just resolve the line spectrally, but emphasize that the mapping science will be done on the integrated moment 0 map.

We have specified an angular resolution of 0.2'' (D~11 AU, R~5.5 AU) for all spectral set ups to resolve the water snow line in TW Hya (~4.7 AU, Zhang+2013), and to map the chemical behavior across all of the major transitions in the disk. The largest angular scale as determined from observations of the CO disk (the maximum possible extent of the molecular emission) in individual velocity channels is 6''.

We aim to detect the H13CN 4-3 and H13CO+ lines in this band. HCN 4-3 was detected with APEX with an integrated flux of 4.9 Jy km/s. We know the approximate CN emitting area (see Fig 2 in the main text, about 1.25''), and if we assume the HCN and CN are emitting from similar regions, we can scale the flux by the beam size over the source size. Additionally, the HCN line is expected to be optically thick, which we correct for. Both H13CN and HCN 4-3 were detected in MWC 380, and the disk averaged optical depth was about ~4. If we assume this optical depth is similar in TW Hya, H13CN should be 13x fainter than HCN. Factoring in both the smaller beam (0.2''/1.25''; where the linear scaling is due to the central concentration of the emission, sigma \propto R^-1), and the factor of 13x for the less abundant isotopologue, we predict that the H13CN peak flux should be 20 mJy. The proposed observations will reach ~5 sigma and will allow us to directly characterize the HCN 4-3 optical depth in this disk vs. radius.

The spectral resolution ranges from ~0.25 km/s to ~0.5 km/s. We have placed a lower resolution window to obtain H2CO and 34SO simultaneously, and on CH3CN in case the emission is weak. We expect N2H+ and DCO+ to be strong and both have high spectral resolution (~0.25 km/s), accordingly. This spectral set up is also designed to use all of the windows for lines without going over the data rate limit of 12 mb/s, while also covering the minimum of 1 GHz in bandwidth total.

We have specified an angular resolution of 0.2'' (D~11 AU, R~5.5 AU) for all spectral set-ups to resolve the water snow line in TW Hya (~4.7 AU, Zhang+2013), and to map the chemical behavior across all of the major transitions in the disk. The largest angular scale as determined from observations of the CO disk (the maximum possible extent of the molecular emission) in individual velocity channels is 6''.

The primary goal of this band is to detect DCN, DCO+, H2CO, and N2H+. DCN 3-2 was detected in a 2.8x2.3 beam with a 300 mJy peak flux. We expect the 4-3 transition to be 2.3x brighter than the 3-2 line according to a Radex model of HCN at 50~K, 10^7 cm^-3. In the 0.2'' beam, assuming the emission is centrally concentrated as R^-1 (i.e., is following the disk surface density), the DCN peak flux for the 4-3 line is expected to be 36 mJy. The DCN window is 0.5 km/s, and thus these observations (4 mJy at 0.25 km/s) will reach 3 mJy in this line and provide a 12 sigma detection of DCN.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CN, CS, SO/34SO, SO2, HC18O+, HCN, H2CO, HDCO

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The channels are between 0.2-0.4 km/s in this band. We have set the resolution to be lower for the HDCO/H213CO/SO2 spectral window so that we can cover all of these lines simultaneously. Likewise, we have lowered the resolution on HC18O+/SO to cover both of these lines as well (we also expect these lines to be weaker). Because we expect the line to be 1-1.4 km/s, we are just sufficiently resolving the lines spectrally and plan to create moment 0 maps to examine the radial structure in the disk spatially.

We have specified an angular resolution of 0.2'' (D~11 AU, R~5.5 AU) for all spectral set ups to resolve the water snow line in TW Hya (~4.7 AU, Zhang+2013), and to map the chemical behavior across all of the major transitions in the disk. The largest angular scale as determined from observations of the CO disk (the maximum possible extent of the molecular emission) in individual velocity channels is 6''.

The faintest line this science goal aims to possibly detect is HC18O+ 4-3 (in a 0.43 km/s channel) if H13CO+ is thick. H13CO+ 4-3 has been detected toward TW Hya with a disk integrated flux of 1.1 Jy km/s. We know from the resolved HCO+ 3-2 map (Cleeves+2015) that the HCO+ emission is centrally peaked and most of the emission comes from within 2.5''. If the H13CO+ 4-3 is thin, the HC18O+ should be a factor of 540/70 fainter, or 7.7. In the 0.2'' beam, we expect the HC18O+ to be 12 mJy, and thus we only expect to detect strong HC18O+ where H13CO+ is optically thick, and thus we should have continuous coverage of HCO+ (in at least one of its isotopologues), at all points in the disk.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Major leaps in sensitivity and spatial resolution afforded by ALMA have opened up the field of protoplanetary disk chemistry, paving the way for chemical surveys and better statistics of disk properties. However, protoplanetary disks are complex objects, both physically and chemically, and as a consequence we need at least one "rosetta stone" to provide an observationally-motivated physical interpretation for unresolved line observations of disks. TW Hya's inclination and nearby proximity make it an ideal target for a survey of T Tauri disk chemistry in situ. We propose a deep, high spatial resolution (0.2") survey of chemistry in the TW Hya disk, where the observations are designed to a) address guaranteed science goals by mapping bright emission lines and b) optimize serendipitous detection of the next set of strong lines expected to be present in disks. The proposed observations have the potential to nearly double our list of molecules detected in the TW Hya disk. These observations will both constrain disk chemical abundances and reveal key physical information about the disk environment, including temperature, ionization, new snow-line locations, and more.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of
Harvard College Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology
